message: In most media, works can be loosely placed on an axis that runs from "Substance" to "Fun." Summer blockbusters sit squarely on the Fun end, while Substantial movies are the ones you keep pushing back in your NetFlix queue. Daniel Starkey wrote this article to better define games' place on that axis, and to describe his thoughts on judging quality and seriousness within the medium: http://tehpwngaming.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=143%3Astarkey-pompus&catid=47%3Alast-added-tutorilas&Itemid=56
I enjoyed the article quite a bit, it is hard to formulate a good post reaction right now though. I will post a relevant response later! :)

I know! It's a really hard question to address. I think that I've spent more time playing games in the Fun camp, but never really get absorbed. When I snap out of game-hypnosis at 3am realizing I've been playing all day, you can bet it was a substantial epic with a great story.

Well written, solid article.  Honestly, bland single-player has kept me away from any real single-player gaming at all for quite a while.  Good multi-player games with strategical depth and an interesting meta game are what I've mainly been playing.  Multi-player goes beyond simple "fun", but it takes a more competitive personality, which definitely isn't everyone's bag.
